description: This car repair shop is run by a local Costa Rican (Mauricio) and his business partner is a Canadian (Johnny) who had a car shop in Canada for 30 years. Johnny inspects all the work done by his mechanics. These guys got the parts I needed from San José the next day and completed the work quickly and professionally. I had tie rods, bushings, brake rotors and an alignment for $250.  It's definitely worth it to make the trip to Jaco to have Johnny look at your rig and let you know what he can do for you. Everyone in town recommended him to me.  Johnny, Mauricio and the clerks all speak English.

name: Tucan trail parking
description: Parking just before the main  entrance of the Observatory Lodge. Toilets. Departure of a trail to Cerro Chato. Free if you pay the entrance for the trails (10 USD/pers). Nice view on the Arenal Volcano.

name: waste ground in front of an old corrida area
description: waste ground, close to small road. Very quiet and safe. Flat.

name: Playa Palma
description: On the beach between trees. Shadow. No need 4X4. Quiet and safe. We stayed 3 nights. Long beach, warm water. Safe to swim.

name: Boruca
description: Area close football field. River. Flat. Very close to the center. Calm.

name: Costa Rica Car Storage
description: Fenced gated yard, secure long and short term parking as part of a small family run business. Family home with dogs on property so vehicle is watched at all times. Warren (owner) is also a Land Rover Technician with a network of other local mechanics to use too. They will coordinate repairs and maintenance while you are away. SJO airport is 25 minutes to one hour depending on traffic. Warren will offer transportation to and from airport or will pick up your vehicle from airport and transport to his storage. Our rate was $110/month (US Dollars), airport transportation included. It is a perfect place for overlanders to leave your home on wheels affordably and safely. Contact Warren at WhatsApp at +506 8818 5647 or wleoncrcarstorage@gmail.com or https://m.facebook.com/costaricacarstorage/ for any questions or reservations.

name: Parqueadero Publico
description:
in front of pizza hut. They let us sleep in the van. 
$2000 until 7am .. after that is $800 hour 
Might be noisy cuz there's a bar next door

name: American Laundry with Hot water
description:
Full service and self Service Laundromat with hot water!!!! Front loader washing machines. 1500 CRC per load.including detergent.

Update: 6500 per load

Update 2019: new prices in the attached picture (C 7000 for up to 8kg and C 8000 for up to 10kg wash & dry self-service)

name: Batsu Colibri
description:
Located in the mountains of San Ramón de Alajuela; within the facilities of Finca Noemy, a farm dedicated to the cultivation and development of coffee, in addition to the conservation of flora and fauna since 1982.

We have a single camping area ideal for travelers with truck campers and motor bikes. It has an amazing view of the mountains with a shelter to cook, relax, and have a fire.

IMPORTANT NOTE: The campsite can only fit one vehicle! Please message ahead of time! We can accommodate multiple vehicles and large RVs but it takes extra coordinating. PLEASE message us ahead on WhatsApp at our business cell phone +506 8803 1966 (English/Spanish via Google Translate). 

In addition to the Camping area, we have 2 Ecolodge cabins equipped for the pleasure of those looking for pleasant rest and connection with nature, they have a maximum capacity of 4 people per cabin.

We have a newly renovated restaurant with a full bar and restaurant. We offer national beers, our own Artisan Cervza, Wine, Rum, Vodka, and Whiskey. The food service is what we call "Modern Tico" which is typical Costa Rican meals with a creative flavorful flair.

We have an external bathroom in walking distance of the camping site. The showers are under construction at the moment.

Our green areas and gardens are suitable for a picnic, or to enjoy a nap in one of our hammocks.

The price per night is ¢6,000 per vehicle. We do not charge by the person! : )

1 motorbike has a minimum charge of ¢6,000. 2 motorbikes is still ¢6,000.

We lock the gate at 8pm! Call and message on WhatsApp (+506 8803 1966) ahead to arrange arrival. We are an active coffee farm and place of dwelling and are not always around.

WE RESERVE THE RIGHT OF ADMISSION.

name: Landrover Taller Bernal Cruz
description:
Very good Landrover Mechanic, works on all kinds of Landrover. Lovely people, know their stuff and love to help out Overlanders.
Phone: 222 1594 / 2253 7536

name: El Rodeo
description: Gas station. Free showers available next to the bathrooms.

name: Cabinas de Maria
description: Very little Clean rooms, hot shower, nice little pool , 20 000 per room (1 double bed), its worth having a look, because from the outside it doesnt look like that. Wifi

name: Wild camping playa Penca
description: Beautiful and quiet wild campingspot on playa Prieto. No facilities. During the day some locals and tourists on the beach, in the evening and early mornings very quiet. Good for swimming. Some shade for camping. Recommended!!

name: Limonales parking lot
description:
If u park right outside Papa Johns you can have wifi , sewer and water connection .
All for free!!
A little noisy, right besides the highway but was okay for us.
Felt safe
Highly recommended for an overnight stop while traveling.
Wifi name: PJ-Limonal
Wifi password: mejoresingredientes
(For sewer use, bring an opening tool)

name: Cahuitas last cowboy laundry
description:
Super well done job! The first place we go that have done a good.
Nice owner.
Super well done , But a expensive.
A basket was 9 dollars (5.000colones)
Recommended!!

name: Cafe Santé
description: Nice ,colourful and relaxing cafe. Very good iced coffee and awesome homemade cakes. It is running by a German lady. stay there for a while , it's worth it!

name: Playa Hermosa
description: Beautiful spot at the top end of Playa Hermosa. Next to a lovely clear fresh water river with cool water (better for cooling down in than the warmer sea) with rope swing. Large area for camping under palm trees slightly set back from the beach. Police have said fine to camp here. Lots of small fire ruminants around from previous campers and some small make shift toilets around. Accessible from main road however small river crossing to cross. Huge beach with great waves. Not too far from town, car park further down the beach offers showers and toilets for 500 colons.

name: Red Frog Coffee Roaster
description:
Little restaurant with amazing food and awesome coffee. Prices are ok, 8$ for a big meal. Owner was very friendly. Best food we had in Costa Rica so far. You can also camp in the backyard. 10$ pp/night only space for 4 rigs. no big rigs.
Hot shower, kitchen, laundry machine and rooms as well.

name: Junquillal Eco Resort - No Camping
description:
They are canadians who take the place, vrsiment a beautiful spot, the beach, the pool, the restaurant, everything is perfect except that there is nothing else .. they allowed us to stay a dozen days , electricity, water, laundry service,
Very nice staff,
I do not know if it will restart the experiment .. but you can always try ..
playa negra just 15 minutes by car
Super surf!
Junquillal the most beautiful beach ..
There is a super market in car 10 minute ..
Not on foot !!
Tamarindo is 35 minutes away
The road is beautiful almost until Junquillal ..

name: Pura Vida mini hostel
description: Hostel with private rooms and dorms well kept, clean, great staff, very helpful, well run, 150 meters to beach, convenient and easy walk to restaurants and bars.

name: Arenal River crossing
description: Nice spot beside Arenal river , plenty of shade nice clean river!  Nice place to camp just a few locals on weekends.

name: Sámara Beach Unda Da Palms
description:
We parked under the palm trees on firm sand for 3 nights.  It gets busy with beachgoers during the day but they clear out after sunset.  On the 3rd day a police officer asked us to park about 10m away in the alley until 6pm.  We set up our table, hammock, chairs and surfed at high tide.  There is even a shower outside the beach bar Las Olas a couple buildings over.  A very nice place if you don’t mind being somewhat on display during the day.  The photo gives you a good idea what we mean.

Also there is pretty good wifi from the neighbouring Spanish School which reaches the beach. Network is Intercultura-Hotspot

name: School Parking
description: Quiet at night nearby school for Free and river close by for having a bath.

name: Dos Brazos
description: Great home community !! Gold panning activity to do! Tour in the park well and more reasonable than leaving Puerto Jimenez. In short quiet possibility of sleeping with vehicles and space arranged for others. Important all the sums paid are for the development of the community !!

name: Hostel villa
description: A nice hostel on the way out of town on the way to La Fortuna. We paid 20,000 for 2 people inc breakfast.

name: Ruinas da Iglesia antigua en Ujarrás
description:
Ruins of the Nuestra Señora de la Limpia Concepción del Rescate Church of Ujarrás. Beautiful building with large garden and picnic tables.
---
Ruinas de la Iglesia Nuestra Señora de la Limpia Concepción del Rescate de Ujarrás.  Bonito edifício con amplio jardin y mesas para picnic.

name: In front of the police station
description:
There's a road between the police station and the cemetery where the police men suggested we park our van.
Safe, free and somewhat quiet.

name: Pura vida hostel Manuel Antonio
description: Dorms for $12 and private rooms $30. Nice place wifi hot showers. Bus stops in front

name: Hotel sirens
description: Beautiful resort hotel on the beach. $62 four bed cabins or $40 single

name: Sergio mechanic
description: speaks only Spanish but we don't  speak much and were able to communicate enough. fixed a problem with engine blocks and fuel pump on land rover discovery. many places in town will deliver parts by courier and is worth the extra money.

name: Mecanico Greibin
description:
ADMIN NOTE: User reports disaster work done on his car.
 
Next to "Tornomecanica". Bad mechanic, bad place!

name: Taller Calvo - Jorge
description: Excellent mechanic. Great person and highly reliable professional. We were stuck here during four days while he repaired all problems our rv had (broken brakes, high temperature at the engine, faulty ‘arrancador’, among others). We even met his family. We will always be grateful with such a person. Not expensive at all. Highly recommended!!

name: Alex launch
description:
perfect cabins for paragliders..
rooms for 25$ a night per person breakfast included. free wifi, swimming pool  pizza restaurant on the other side.. high place. nice view. stiff road tho, for the big rigs.

name: Room 2 board hostel
description:
Amazing hostel with private and shred rooms. Great pool, 1/2 block to beach. Yoga classes upstairs, surf camp, affordable excellent bar restaurant,  great pool, roof top deck with hammocks and view to the waves, very clean and great experience. I've been here many times and it is consistent and excellent every time. This time I asked to camp in my vw bus in the parking lot and Bryan the owner was gracious and welcoming and for $10 / night we enjoyed the facility and pool and WiFi.
A great experience.

name: Dixon' s Place
description: Kitchen area shower restroom big lot with grass area with trees around wood stove hammocks and little house to hang out!! No indication about camping, but at that price why not take a room with a fan?

name: Mirador La Torre

name: Costa Rica Border
description:
Procedure to enter Costa Rica:

1. As you exit Nicaragua, pass the line of trucks. It is very narrow so try to find your way carefully.

2. There is an office of immigration for trucks. They don't do tourists. You need to wait for the truck before you pass and you go through fumigation.

3. As you exit fumigation, keep to your right. Soon you will see the immigration offices. Park wherever you can.

4. Stamp your passport. This can be a 5-minute or a 45-minute process depending on if there were some buses of people before you. Super friendly immigration officers. 

5. Right across the street there is where you get a form for TIP. You fill out the form, the officer signs it. You also get paper ticket with your vehicle registration number.  With this form, you walk or drive 100 meters further. 

6. There is a modern building with security in front of it where you can get insurance ($56 or the equivalent in colon, no credit card) and your TIP.

7. As you exit the border area, you need to give them a paper ticket with your vehicle registration number. 

Notes: 

1) You don't need copies of any documents. You don't need to pay any fees (apart from mandatory insurance).
2) Many travelers report that insurance purchased in Guatemala that should cover Costa Rica is not accepted.

description: Showed up in the valley late 7:00pm Sunday with nothing open. Catara Del Toro closes at 6:00pm and camping bajos de toro gates were too narrow for our Rover Defender 110. So with no options left we were going to park/camp in the parking lot of this restaurant. After looking over maps and trying to figure out what next, Kenneth came from the A-frame house above to offer us a campsite. Beautiful grassy knolls with enough room for huge outfits. Clean cold showers and clean bathrooms. Fireflies that look like airplanes, this place was a delight! If I remember correctly it was around $2-$6 US per person a night. Very close to the river of unreal aqua blue waters. I do believe the restaurant is only open Friday and Saturday but please do not quote me on that.

name: Parismina River
description: By the river, good for swimming fresh water Rocky banks a little cliff for good jump into the river, many trees and good shade, safe, kind of isolated spot, few cars passing by, during the night we spent only 2 cars, many spots in the area, there is one more spot less than 1 km on the right, river is seen from the road, there is a farm house in front, you pay 5 dollars for camping for car! No 4wd needed, great spot!!!! Good spear fishing

name: Selina
description: Great hostel. Pool, garden, restaurant, bar, all right on the beach. A bit overpriced but it is CR after all. $20/n for 6 bed dorm. Many sleeping options available.

name: Oropéndola Waterfall
description:
Nice waterfall with a small natural pool where you can swim. Water was quite cold, and because of Semana Santa, it was packed. Probably would be more empty during the week.
The bad part - they raised the price to bordering with ridiculous 10 usd per person. For a small, albeit nice waterfall it's just way too much I think. We didn't know, because of the lack of info on the internet, so I am putting it here. In hindsight, we'd probably pay 5$ more and go check out the national park.
If money is no issue at all, it was nice to see though.

name: Mirador / Viewpoint
description:
Beautiful viewpoint with a very friendly owner who maintains the property. There's no entry fee but I would recommend 1000 per person.
Camping on the property might be possible as well. Just ask. A lot of wildlife around. Standard 2WD Gravel to the property.

name: Parking mall Multiplaza
description:
Apparently the largest mall in CR. Plenty of posh boutiques and restaurants, even a supermarket.
I asked a security guard if I could park for the night, he directed me to the parking staffs, finally spoke with Alberto from the parking office who accepted at a rate of 4k per day. Means if you come at 8pm and leave next day any time, its 4k. If you come before, you got to pay for that day too (8k then). Not official, but everyone helpful.
Parking is level, ultrasafe and rather quiet after the mall closes at 9pm.

Not soo busy . Some restaurant around and supermarket . Nothing special but cool after the bad road from the border . ;)

name: Nicaragua Entry
description:
ENTER NICARAGUA:

Lots of guys will approach you as soon as you exit Costa Rica. Police check passports and they do the first fumigation.

my advice is to get the help of one of these guys which was very helpful and let you skip annoying conversations and potential arguments with very unprofessional border police.

step 0: before you go to Nicaragua, get a copy of your temporary import permit from Costa Rica, a copy of your driver's license and a copy of your registration.

1. once at the main building, you need to approach the doors and find the custom guy near the door who has the form that you need to fill up.

2. There's a guy with a high visibility vest who does the "inspection" of your vehicle.

3. with that form signed, go to the insurance place and pay the $12 for 1 month of insurance.

4. Now go inside and get your passport stamped by customs. 
No yellow fever certification or permission to enter the country is required. 
pay $2 dollars plus $10 to enter the country.

5. Go outside and find a guy that sells the "rodaje" permit, which costs $5.

6. Go to the small police hut on the opposite side of the entrance, across the parking, to get the "vehicle inspection" done by the police. they will take your copies and stamp your initial form.

7. with this, you can go to the back of the passport stamping desks and get your temp permit printed out. There's a desk at the back, behind the x-ray machines, where there's a guy with a desktop computer and a printer that does the job.

8. with this, you can now go to the exit where you will only need to pay another $3 for the fumigation. 

____

Valores que pagamos em fevereiro de 2024: $ 13 dólares por pessoa para entrar + $ 10 dólares para nosso cachorro. Logo após sair da fronteira já pode comprar o seguro: $ 12 dólares por 1 mês.

—-

Amounts we paid in February 2024: $13 dollars per person to enter + $10 dollars for our dog. Right after leaving the border you can buy insurance: $12 dollars for 1 month.

name: La Fortuna
description: Nice place, dorms, private rooms, clean, ac

name: Public Beach Parking Lot
description: We wanted to spend a day biking in Las Catalinas, but were unable to find a close spot to camp. We spoke with the security of the resort and they would not let us stay in our van in their public lot. We also spoke with a guy who was taking money to watch the cars at the public beach parking lot and he suggested to not stay overnight there, although legal and allowed, he warned of robberies... which we doubted. We ended up parking on the road about 100 feet south of the public beach parking lot and it worked out fine. Contruction early woke us up, but nobody bothered us there. Las Catalinas has public outdoor showers by the beach and public restrooms. Pura Vida Ride bike shop was really helpful too, would suggest stopping by for bike rentals or whatever you need. Mountain biking in the area was decent also, but would suggest heading south on the trail first.

name: Public Beach Access
description:
After doing the bioluminescent kayaking we were looking for a place to camp overnight in our van before catching the ferry in the morning. We found this spot, which is a public beach access spot with parking area and it looked like a really decent place to stay. We spoke with a "glamping" place that was being constructed next to it and they told us it was definitely ok to stay there. They also offered to let us use their restroom/shower if needed (although we didn't use them and cant comment on them) and had a really friendly security guard check in with us. 
There's a water tap on the side of the glamping building.
You can pee in nearby in the woods!


Keep in mind the tide however. We woke up with the water very close to our van. Do not park on the beach. Stay in the parking area.

name: JSM 24 horas
description: Nice looking petrol pump where you can refill the propane

name: Hotel Posada del Tope
description:
Small hotel with an old style decoration, nice garden and helpful staff.

The room with shared bathroom costs 24 dollars (taxes not included)

I don't know how much is the private room with private bathroom.

They have refrigerator and microwave if you want to use it and also refill the bottle of water.

Good location just 150 meters from the center and about 1 kilometer from the bus station

name: Street parking in front of Cahuita pizzeria
description: Level and shaded, large enough for any rig size provided space is available. Very quiet.

name: Santa Elena cloud forest reserve
description: The reserve is a really good alternative for the private; crowded and expensive Monteverde NP. Se paid 10000 colones for an adult and 4000 for children from 8 to 12. There are 4 different trails. Less people = more chance to see wildlife. Day Use Only, Signs posted and enforced. We asked for permission to sleep here but it was not possible.

name: in the cloud forest
description:
just à little place to spend the night if you plan to go hike in the Santa Elena réserve
not really flat but you can manage with some staff ( i cant find thé word in english 😉)
possible to stay from 4.30pm to 8 am ... the rest of Time it s Shuttle place for the zipline from thé selvatura Park
we ve been here with our RV

name: Ruinas de Ujarrras
description: We stayed one night in the place, extremely quiet. Big space!!!

name: Archeological site Finca 6
description: Interesting archeological site of ancient stone globes and a good museum explaining it all. Worth a stop between Uvita and Penisula Osa. $6

name: Hotel Los Volcanes
description:
Small hotel in front of the main road, offers private rooms for 32-35 dollars with hot water, TV, fan, and an small fridge in the room. The room doesn't have A/C (at least mine, probably expensive rooms have A/C).

The staff is helpful and the room is clean and good enough to rest after one day of hiking.

The hotel has also kitchen and a swimming pool.

name: Piuri Rio Celeste
description:
Parking, cabins, camping, restaurant natural spring fountain and private access to the beautiful river. 
Cabin rental is $50usd. Parking options depend on vehicle height. We took the upper lot, just past the water fountain. We had views of the hills and a peek at the river. He lifted the power line and our camper cleared it with no issues. Could be messy if muddy and rainy. But not today. 
The places near the park charge $5 and $10 just for parking.  Then NP fees on top. Plus you CANNOT swim in the river inside the park. This place has a private trail down to a great swimming hole. 
The restaurant will prepare a delicious, large típico meal upon request. We had delicious fish. The people are extremely friendly and welcoming. 
The road in this area is newly paved. This place is just past the NP on the curve overlooking the river. Easy walk to the park for the hikes and waterfalls.

name: Donde Pablo Hostel
description:
Pablo is owner, speak well English, very enthusiastic guy
It is a nice hostel, Motorcycle friendly 
It is a small town, every place there are walkable

name: River ferry
description: C5,000 for our truck (6t, Iveco Daily 4x4) to cross the river. Might be cheaper for smaller vehicles.  Bit pricey but worth it to cut the corner between Penisula Osa and Uvita. Route from south of the river across to the main Golfo Dulce road is a lovely drive with great views down along the coast, but it's a dirt road, needing high-clearance and ideally 4x4, even in the dry season.

name: Difficult for Big Rigs
description: Drakes is not an easy place for big-rigs. No problem to arrive here or get around, but we found nowhere we could park-up  (paid or free). It's a tiny, cramped village and all the spots we found had size restrictions/height barriers etc. We are L 6m, W 2.2m, H 3.3m. We ended up not staying here. Not worth the drive here for larger rigs.

name: Canaan Village
description:
Even if you're not going to do any of the long hikes, this little village is well worth the short detour to visit. 

There is

- a cheese making place selling lovely cheeses of different flavours. Very good prices. Don't be put off that the approach looks like a house, the cheese dairy is round the back. Katya will explain the process if you want & let you taste.

- a fine-chocolate making place with lots of great tastings & choc for sale. Not cheap but great quality.

- a nice little restaurant for lunch with imaginative menu (good prices by CR standards)

- some short walks and great scenery.

name: Parque Reptilandia
description: We generally don't like animal parks or zoos but this place seems very well run with good conditions for the reptiles. We spent a fascinating morning here. The staff were friendly and well-informed, answering questions in English. They showed us some baby vipers that had just been born an hour before we got there. Expensive at $12pp, but we enjoyed it and kids would love it here.

name: Montana trucha de Chachi
description:
Nice parking of a restaurant , but just open on saturday and sunday . The boss of this truts and vegetable farm was very gently . It was free for us , that's probably change on the futur .  Very good,beautiful and calm spot on the wild montain . There water , toilets ...
There is a very narrow road and growning up . It was ok with our 24 feet rv with back propulsion but without it's could be difficult . There is a very small river to accross but cool before the raining season .

name: Parador Turistio
description:
We sleep next to the hostel, we ask permission from the owners, they are extremely kind. The night a little noisy because a lot of trucks pass by the route. The temperature is pleasant.
There is wifi, the network is called Iguanas Wharf.
---
Dormimos pegado al parador, pedimos permiso a los dueños, son sumamente amables. La noche un poco ruidosa porque pasan muchisimos camiones por la ruta. La temperatura es agradable. 
Hay wifi, el usuario es Iguanas Muelle.

name: Hostel Chill Out Arenal
description:
The hostel offers private room with private bathroom for 20 dollars, and tents for 5 dollars.

The hostel has a kitchen outside, very basic but useful, also a shower (very basic also)

The owners were friendly, they gave us info about the activities around and also they offers a tour for 30 dollars if you want to do two or three activities in one day.

name: Bamboocha
description: Restaurant with italien chef. The food is very very good and the place is welcoming. ☝️Clean toilets

name: Pura Vista Glamping
description:
This campground is a start-up. It’s a flat area with gate. It’s near the butterfly conservatory and it has a beautyful view of the volcano and the lake. There is electricity, water, WiFi and a bathroom. Call Pura Vista Glamping +50660221037 or check Instagram https://instagram.com/pura_vista_glamping?igshid=NzZlODBkYWE4Ng==

+506 60221037 or Whatsapp +2975929535

name: ARB 4x4 Accessories
description:
Outstanding 4x4 shop / mechanics.  Will help you diagnose, repair or get you parts needed.  Don't rip you off but fix problem.  

Also ARB distributor in CR but did several repairs / replacements on my 1999 Jeep. 

Like all 4x4 shops not budget friendly but I got exactly what I paid for.  Run by 3 daughters of Niels Cruz. 

I reached out on Facebook and Priscillia responded very quickly.

Www.arbcostarica.com

name: SERC S.A.  - Solar energy specialist
description:
Good specialist place for solar panels, batteries (incl lithium), battery chargers and battery management systems and relays. General electronics for solar systems. Roberto Kruse speaks good English & German he was really helpful with us. +506 2273 4545   ventas@sercsa.com  ww.sercsa.com
07:30 to 17:00 Mon/Fri
We are also Victron Energy repair center https://www.victronenergy.com./markets/automotive

name: Hostel Finca Escalante
description: Nice hostel and very friendly manager Warren let us park-up in the car-park and sleep in our truck. This is the only place we found in San Jose that we could fit into. There are wires across the gate. We are 3.3m high and we only just got under them by lifting them up with a stick. Any taller won't fit in. Once you're in, there's plenty of space in the car park for up to med/large sized rigs (not for very big rigs). Good bathrooms/hot showers in the hostel. Small chill-out area out the back with hammocks in trees. Good wifi most of the time (bit slow at peak times). Electric plug-in available but we didn't need it (good solar).  Peaceful place. Great location in nice part of town, close to nice cafés bars & restaurants. $15pn for 2 people & truck.

name: CASEM COOP and La Cuchara Abuela
description:
The shop in front is filled with hand crafts made by area women ranging in age from 20 to 80. A huge variety of products are available with artists credited. Even a notebook introducing each crafter in the huge cooperative. Decent prices.
The area in back is a restaurant run by the same cooperative. Amazing food made grandma style at great prices.  And next door is an organic market. They do allow overnight parking here but the lot isn’t really large.

name: Iglesia Palma Norte
description: Approached the fire station first but they suggested that I approached the church. Church welcome me travelling on skateboard. cyclists are welcome as well. The father gave me a store room to sleep with a mattress and fan. WiFi is in the park next to the church.

name: Sebas’ Garage
description:
NEW NUMBER on WhatsApp +506 7178 9739

Sebastian takes care of the US Embassy’s cars and came highly recommended by our Air BnB owner. He came out to diagnose our suspension issue at 9pm at night!  He was professional, quick, and generally a nice guy. Excellent English. Highly recommend!

name: Pitstop Garage
description: Bernie is a trustworthy, English speaking mechanic that we were surprised to be referred to by 2 independent sources. He couldn’t fix our problem but diagnosed it as a 4x4/transmission issue and recommend his 4x4 guy at Coche Tuning.

name: VS&S
description: Paint shop and they wash cars. I got the interior done for 10,000colones and they are even trying to fix my back seat release. Nice guys.

name: Tranmisiones Mundiales
description: Got our transmission rebuilt here and a new soloniod. Not very much English spoken here, but they seemed honest. We had to pay about 1,000,000 (925,000 without tax), but that’s about what it would cost in California I think for a Honda Ridgeline. Costa Rica is not cheap.

name: Armonía Ambiental
description: This is the nicest family with rustic cabins to rent for 5000 colones per person with private rooms and home cooked meals for a reasonable price. They have private rock climbing and a huge tree to climb on the property. Also farm animals for the kids. You could fit small to medium rigs here but you probably want 4x4 and it is steep coming in (our brakes were jello). Their son Dario speaks great English. Info@armoniaambiental.net 8707 1102

name: Cabinas Eddy B&B
description:
Good place to rest, rooms with shared bathroom costs 30 usd and with private bathroom costs 35/45 usd more less, the rooms and the place in general is quite clean.

The price includes a really good breakfast.

If you negotiate the price of the accommodation/tours (and pay by cash) you could get a discount here

name: Poza Azul
description:
Seems to be a nice place to park for a night. We didn't stay but large parking in front of the waterfall entrance. 

Free and refreshing waterfall with nice pool.

name: Sea spot
description: Nice place here in front of the sea . A lot of shadow . there us a lot of small parking along the sea. You can drive a little further to find more spots. no servive but beautiful ,calm,safe for us and free. A tourist give the wifi password of the lisa house : LISA CASA

name: Selina parking
description:
I stayed 2 nights in my car in the hotel's lot. Nobody told me anything. 
Public Restroom available in plaza Kahuna near by. FREE.

name: River crossing - Cano Seco
description: River crossing. About 40cm deep in dry season.

name: Gasolinera Katira
description:
Tiene un amplio playon donde por la noche paran camiones, Super seguro, ideal para pasar la noche si uno va a Rio Celeste. La estación tiene baños. 

It has a large play area where trucks stop at night, Super safe, ideal to spend the night if one goes to Rio Celeste. The station has bathrooms.

name: Pegado al restaurante
description:
Al lado del restaurante sabor tico hay un predio enorme bajo un árbol gigante sumamente tranquilo y seguro. De noche la policía pasa varias veces. Pasamos una tranquila noche en este lugar. 

Next to the restaurant, there is a huge property under a giant tree that is extremely quiet and safe. At night the police pass several times. We spent a quiet night in this place.

name: En la playa
description:
El lugar es muy amplio y cómodo, se entra por el camino del bar la Lora Amarilla. Por la tarde se llena de gente que viene a ver el atardecer. Estuvimos dos noche. En toda la zona están habiendo varios robos. Tanto la policía, locales y otros viajeros nos advirtieron que después de las 11 de la noche no dejemos nada suelto. Estuvimos dos noches y no vimos ni sentimos nada. 
The place is very spacious and comfortable, you enter through the path of the Lora Amarilla bar. In the afternoon it is full of people who come to watch the sunset. We stayed two nights. There are several robberies throughout the area. Both the police, locals and other travelers warned us that after 11 o'clock at night we did not leave anything loose. We stayed two nights and did not see or feel anything.

name: Sueños Del Tesoro
description:
A nice quiet campsite on top of the hill with oceanview on Drake Bay.
Good clean facilities. We payed 12500 colones (around 20 USD) for 2 persons + truck with rooftop tent.
Owner speaks only Spanish.

name: parqueo publico
description:
We slept here with our camper 3,2 m hight. 
Negotiate for 10$ a night. 
Nothing special but the only here we could fit in.

name: Costa Rican Vehicle Insurance
description: When you enter Costa Rica with your own vehicle you MUST buy a 3 months (minimum period) insurance policy. This is only 3rd party liability insurance. The price was &56 usd February 6, 2024. Don't need copies, just original passport, title, registration and the form you filled at the customs before. Buy insurance at window on right. Take that insurance paper to window on left to obtain TIP. Easy

name: Camping El Jardín
description: Nice couple runs this place. Simple but tidy sandy lot. Clean bathrooms and stalls with pipe showers. Sinks for washing. Electricity. A block from the beach, next to a great supermarket. Wifi if you ask. Some tree limbs, but we are 3m tall and managed. 4000 pp/pn.

name: Park camp
description: Perfect place to stay near río celeste as there are no many other places. Free and safe, very quiet night.

name: perfect spot wild camping
description: ADMIN NOTE: as per Maritime Law wild camping is prohibited in maritime zones, fines will be enforced. NO Camping allowed.

name: last piece of road
description: river view at the very last end of the road. if you pass los angeles and the natural reserve you will get there. just follow the cordinates. amazing view with hige rocks but still possible to swim. the trails are use by the natural reserve. we spoke with locals and they said that will be fine to camp. the car needs to stay on the road and need an 4x4 to get here.

name: Aventuri Ticos
description:
Luis and his wife, overlanders themselves, welcome travelers to park for FREE in their secure private property, with bathrooms wifi and everything you need. Good for big cars too. I stayed here one night, great hospitality from them. In addition, Luis buy and sell cars so he might help you with yours. whatsapp +506 8381-7373
Facebook:   Aventuri Ticos

name: Peloqueria / Friseur / Hair Cuts
description: Runia, a nice Costa Rican lady runs her small salon. Very friendly. Speaks only a very few words English but together with my very little words of Spanish we manages pretty well.

name: Mirador Del Bosque
description: Great views from the campsite over Laguna Hule. Not to miss camping spot if you’re in the area, the sunrise is amazing. Camping is part of a restaurant, they will open the gates to the campground if you ask in the restaurant. We paid 3,000 colones pppn. 30 min hike down to the lagune. Basic shower and toilet, some covered cooking areas with chairs and bbq’s available to use. The camping is at the end of a 20-minute dirt road. Take the 126 from San Miguel, then follow the signs for Laguna Hule.

name: Street Parking near Basilica for Big Rigs
description: Coming from San Jose on CA-2 you will pass the basilica on your left. Turn left at the 2nd street (after Plaza Deportes Los Angeles). There is parking on the left for a couple of rigs. Will probably have the usual traffic noise.

name: Jaguar rescue center
description: $20 to get in. Probably it’s a nice spot but once we found out that there were no jaguar at the moment we did not go in

name: Cloudbridge Nature Reserve
description:
I found this place on TripAdvisor, but for some reason, only a few people go there. During the rainy season, the road is 4*4 only, we drove a Toyota 4Runner and were fine. 
Cloudbridge is a private nature reserve, and I believe, it's the only place in Costa Rica with entrance by donation, where 100% of income goes back into the running and reforestation of the reserve, education of local and international students, conservation of primary forest habitats and studying the local flora, fauna and impacts of the reforestation efforts within the reserve.
There are amazing views and waterfalls, no-one was there during our visit, only one volunteer, who works at the Main Station and can provide you info about trails and animals. There are walking poles, which I highly recommend to use. If you like, you can swim in the waterfall, but it's really cold. There are also bathrooms in the parking lot and pit toilet in the middle of the trail.
To sum up, it is our favorite hiking place in Costa Rica.

name: Multiserviceos Zurqui
description: Light and heavy vehicles. Laser alignment. Oil change. Balance and rotate. Mechanical work. Welding. Good prices. Good people.

name: Sol y Mar cabins
description: Nice clean cabins with bathroom, sky tv fan and large kitchen, right by nice beach, we paid 40US for a cabin with three double beds, definitely the best option around here, safe parking, friendly owners , several different cabins available

name: Hotel Bambu Beach
description: Rooms, cabinas and parking/camping. Showers, bathrooms, and kitchen for you to use. Clean, super quiet and Jesus (the owner) super friendly. We paid 3000 pp for truck camping. Wifi - useless.

name: Wild Camping near Road to Rincon Vieja Santa Maria
description: Large even spot near gravelroad to rincon vieja  sector Santa Maria. Quiet, no traffic, peacefull. Good for staiying  overnight.

name: Everything Adventures
description: place to buy camping gas bottles and some climbing stuff

name: Cabañas Riverside
description:
Really lovely spot, next to the nacional parc. Here you can also find some special wild animals. One morning there was a family of monkeys, another one a Tucan,  and everywhere are some crabs and leguanes. 
In the backyard you can also find special animals. ;) ask Peck the kindly owner, if he can show you.
Best recommendation in Cahuita.

We paid 25$ for night in a double room
after 3 nights we get a special price. It's really nice and clean. Perfect place to relax.

name: Cabinas carol
description: They let us park here for few nights. Bathroom, shower, kitchen, electricity and wifi. $12 for 2 people and camper per night. So far so good. Owner, Pablo, friendly and helpful.

name: HA Alpha / Logistica
description:
This is an Almacen Fiscal where you can store your van to get your TIP suspended.  Open Monday-Friday, 9am-5pm.  They take care of all the paperwork, including Aduana, when you store your van.  But when you pick up, you'll need to go first to Aduana at Liberia airport. 200usd for the first 8 days , 4 usd per additional day
Full write-up of how to do this available here: 
http://www.monkeysontheroad.com/how-to-keep-your-vehicle-in-costa-rica-longer-than-90-days

name: Parks la Laguna
description: perfect boondocking spot. no facilities but the lake is right at your front door. very windy when we were here and a bit of rain but that's just the crazy weather here. looks like some cars have gotteb stuck here before but probably when it was very rainy. easy to get here and free.

name: dominical supermarket
description: way better super market than most in CR and prices are not inflated like in town. friendly staff

name: resto/bar/rooms/parking/rodeo
description: We did not stay here but stopped here after a long hike ride for a beer, talked to the manager, got free amazing ceviche which was actually good (most places are subpar to our ceviche standards). this place has a rodeo on Saturdays (however you feel about that) and they have a very nice kitchen and bar. about 18 rooms to rent and lots of space for any kind of rig. I think if you have dinner and/or beers you can stay here free. They close at midnight and have services like water, electricity, toilets, and showers. highly recommend staying here if not staying at a beach or something.

name: Playa Langosta street parking
description: We parked across the street from the big hotels, across from the entrance path to playa langosta. There’s a piece of land with trees and dirt, we parked right there. The guard of the hotel was okay with it. Very safe option! The other public beaches/parking lots are supposedly dangerous. No amenities at all, but suitable for big rigs.

name: Desmonte Community Center
description: Covered area, play area, sinks with running water, soccer field, parking. This is a quiet little community park. Would be great to get out of the rain here if on bikes. Electrical outlet but didn’t test. Water worked.

name: Tortugero 7 Backpackers
description:
Very good hostel nice staff all its new very good price 10usd with breakfast 
8usd without breakfast.
Recommended!

name: Laundry located in Plaza Palmas.
description: Laundry service or do it yourself. Just past the hustle and bustle, so plenty of parking. Even space for big rigs. Likely unnoticed if parked overnight (we were). Also on Thursdays is a night market with music and vendors.  A few good places to eat nearby.

name: Organico (vegan, vegetarian and gluten free food)
description: A tasty restaurant that caters to healthy food as well as vegetarians, vegans and gluten-free diets.  Menu offerings run from $5 to $15 usd. They also have items like granola, cookies, oils, coffee, drinks including a gluten free beer, palo santo, bamboo straws, natural sun screen, etc for sale.

name: Huge plain field
description:
Just 400m next to Rio Negro Hot Springs is a big plain field which can accommodate tents and campervans.
Looks like a former construction site, but is now with grass overgrown. Nice and cool with a steady wind blowing any insects away...FREE!

name: Mc Donalds Parkinglot
description: We asked if we can stay overnight, because it gets dark. They agreed, but the people who allowed us to stay overnight weren’t the manager or something. They were friendly and also told us its a very safe place. Quiet night, accept from some normal street-noises, but we slept very well. Good wifi connection also outside in the van.

name: Hostel VidaMar
description:
Three female entrepreneurs recycled shipping container into a very cool hostel with big rooms with AC and private bathroom for $24 (best deal in town)!

In addition, the private rooms have TV (with HBO) and WiFi and are just opposite the public beach access to Santa Teresa Beach.

Free gated parking with option to sleep in the car or pitch a tent for $5...or dorm for $12.

Loved my stay here with my dog.

(Hot showers & free drinking water are in the works)

name: Koji’s Sushi
description:
Amazingly fresh sashimi and sushi prepared by Japanese chef Koji!
Reasonably priced and big variety, including huge Wagyu & Angus steaks! 
Also on offer Costa Rican Craft Beer 🍻 

Oh, and dog friendly :)

name: Bahia BeachFront Hôtel & Restaurant
description:
Small hotel located on the edge of the beach and run by Elise and Eric a very nice French couple. Establishment nickel and far from the noise nuisance of Samara. A nice stop in our tour of the Americas. Excellent value. The restaurant only serves breakfast.
--
Petit hôtel situé en bordure de plage et tenu par Elise et Éric un couple de français super sympas. Établissement nickel et loin des nuisances sonores de Samara. Une petite halte bien appréciable dans notre tour des Amériques. Excellent rapport qualité-prix. Le restaurant ne sert que les petits déjeuners.

name: Land Rover Parts (Repuestos Europeos)
description:
Land Rover Parts, with lots of them in stock, also for TD5s. Also has a small workshop, not sure if you can use it, we just needed a part and already had a place to work. 
Phone/Whatsapp: +506 8836 5460

name: Hostel Finca Escalante
description: Nice hostel and very friendly manager Warren let us park in the carpark and sleep in our truck. This is the only place we found in San Jose that we could fit into. There are wires across the gate and branches too. We are 3.3m high and we only just got under them by lifting them up with a stick. Any taller won't fit in. Once you're in, there's minimal space in the car park for up to small-sized rigs (not for anything bigger). Good bathrooms/hot showers in the hostel. Small chill-out area out the back with hammocks in trees. Good wifi most of the time (bit slow at peak times). Electric plug-in available but we didn't need it (good solar). Peaceful place. Great location in nice part of town, close to nice cafés bars & restaurants. $15pn for 2 people & truck.

name: Blackall (license plates)
description: This is a full service photography and print shop. They can print high quality color graphics, stickers, passport photos and license plates. They made these on a hard plastic for us. 4 for $25.00usd.  Check out the photos, you can barely tell the difference. They look perfect!

name: Intensivet 24h
description:
24hr veterinary clinic with English speaking personnel. 
Email: info@hospitalintensivet.com
Tel: (506) 2291 9001 (24hrs)

name: Casa Linda
description: Great host, wonderful couple who will give lot of great tips, they love overlanders, great place to stay, near to Manuel National Park

name: AMS-tuning DPF (diesel particulate filter)
description: Danilo Compus is a guy with lots of knowledge about DPF software and is able to remove the DPF message from your car computer. So if you are considering to disable or remove your filtet contact this guy. Europe, US or Japanese cars. He is in contact with Europe for assist with specific problems. The price depends on the type of car but with some bargain you should be able to get a reasonable price.  Its hard to find company's in Latin America that can do this kind of work. Maybe in Chile you will have success  again.. call or what's app him in advance. His English is not perfect but you will be fine. He is an honest guy that truely wants to help overlanders. +506 72745351

name: Ligia's Place
description:
Note: the GPS point is not completely accurate as I couldn't get a GPS lock there (but should be within 50 or so). The place is on the left side about 150m along the road as you take the right fork as you enter the main part of Dos Brazos (ie at the school and pulpería). If you get to the first segmented concrete bridge, you've gone too far, the place is immediately before this bridge. I included a picture of the house from the entrance. 

Ligia offers camping and parking with an out-building that has a toilet and showers (it used to be the El Tigre pulpería).  Ligia and her husband Wilner are both very friendly and welcoming. They have a dog, Tigre, who is very relaxed. 

The house is right next to the first entrance to the El Tigre trailer, which is a 7ish hour loop that passes through Corcodavo park. You need permission and payment (you probably can't do this in Dos Brazos) to actually enter the park (although this is likely not checked) and perhaps a guide - but you can walk for perhaps an hour and a half up the trail without entering the park and have the chance to see the same animals. You can do the same from the other trail entrance (it's a loop) which is perhaps 10 minutes down the road right before a small blue building (with a sign mentioning the El Tigre park). 

There is a fairly fancy tourist information building as well, if you take the left fork on coming into town, although we couldn't find the staff member when we stopped by (but they are apparently there all day). Lots of tours on offer. 

Ligias yard has room for several vehicles, although only some spots are flat. Shade is available, but maybe not easily for taller vehicles. 

Prices are negotiable as of this moment, expect to pay between 2000 and 5000 depending on what services you want. I highly recommend a stop in Dos Brazos.

name: Flutterby Hostel
description:
Camping at the Hostel parking. 10$ per person. WiFi was ok when it was working. Free bananas and water. Well stocked kitchen available. 
Shower only cold, nice bar with craft beer. Not for big rigs and entry height restriction is about 2.5m, maybe lower.
Be aware that entry to the beach during the day is another 6$pp because it’s a National Park.

name: Super servicio
description: Good selection of quality oil, fast, friendly!

name: Mina el Aguacate
description: Abandoned gold mine. Nice river to swim in with natural pools and slides. You can hike up to the old mine tunnel, keep an eye for the cows because they go in too. There’s a few flat spots to park. The entrance is after the bridge on the right, go through a small red gate

name: parking grass1
description: Roadside parking in front of some restaurants. 100m to NP entrance, free day/nightparking. Weak wifi from the townpark (zii). We stayed here for two nights and no one bothered us.

name: Punto Vet
description: Very friendly staff. We took our dog there to get his vaccines updated. He needed bordatella, leptospirosis and rabies and we were charged c33,000.

name: Hostel Tortuga
description: In middle of the beautiful Jungle Costa Ricas, nearby by a calm River. You can camp and use the Showers, Sharing Kitchen or Pool or rent some Basic Rooms with AC and Hot Water. Our Hostel is surrounded of wonderfull Beaches and Waterfalls. Just ask for the Secret Spots. Pura Vida.

name: Camel service car
description:
a few KMS from the Sixaola border, very good service, secure parking, 100% recommended,
we change to our truck (Renault traffic) box oil, engine oil and engine filter, no problem and very good prices.

lubricentro a pocos KMS de la frontera Sixaola, muy buen servicio, predio con seguridad para aparcar, 100% recomendable,  
nosotros le cambiamos a nuestra  camioneta ( Renault tráfic) aceite de caja, aceite de motor y filtro de motor, ningún problema y precios muy buenos.

name: Yes-point
description: perfect boondock site, right in the corner of the road and a little bit up. It is a flat area, also perfect for big rigs. no facilities but the view is stunning! also very much privacy because the road is about 10-15 meters away. We stayed with a 4WD with rooftop tent from Nomad America. Also, it can be a bit windy at night.

name: Minas del aguacate parking area
description:
Parking lot of the mine/river. Beautiful spot in the forest by a river. Locals come to swim and drink on weekends but probably leave at the end of the day. Close to the road but zero traffic during the night. No facilities.

 Could probably fit a big rig, road in is partially unpaved and narrow but not steep.

free!

name: Toll to San Jose
description:
Try to not pay in USD here - we gave the guy 20usd and he gave us back 13usd (which means he kept 4usd for himself, as toll was less than 3).
Not much but just make sure you check your change!

name: Taller La Mandarina
description:
We had a rear brakes issue and Alan fixed it in a morning and left them as new!
Really friendly guy - he’s planning on travelling down the PanAm with his girlfriend soon so he is really happy to meet other overlanders! 
It is right across the AM/PM, large black garage door. Open from 8am.
Great job and perfect price! 100% recommended!

name: Malanoche Estuary,  Sámara bay
description:
Great little spot on the beach at southern end of Sámara bay. We stayed tucked away in front of a number of private properties, all of which appear unoccupied, but loads of space near to makeshift football pitch. Easy drive down to flat, compacted sand - no need for 4x4 and plenty of space. looks to be a bar/restaurant just up the beach.
I

name: Electromecanico Pele
description:
Here we fix the starter of our 1960 car. Very friendly, he showed us clearly what the problem was and what arrangement to make. He solved it in less than an hour. Fix: starter coil starter cost 12,000 colones (approx 24 dollars)

acá arreglamos el arrancador (burro de arranque) de nuestro auto de 1960. Muy amable, nos mostró claramente cuál era el problema y que arreglo hacerle. lo resolvió en menos de una hora. Arreglo: enfundar bobina del motor de arranque costo 12.000 colones (aprox 24 dólares)

name: Quetzal trail to tree
description:
This is where we parked to see 4 Quetzals in a tree. There is a little, steep, muddy hiking trail near this parking spot. Hike up at 5:30-6 am and you’ll see lots of people there with guides. The hike on the trail is short. 
The road to get to this spot in San Gerardo de Dota is steep and narrow but mostly paved. People just park on the sides of the narrow road at the trailhead. No designated parking spots and vehicles barely fit.

name: Secret beach
description: Someone pointed us out to this beach spot, only some locals go here. You can park your car at the fisherman's place or just a bit further down the road. at the end of the road there is a gate you are not allowed to pass, take the footpath on the right side and continue for 100 meters, the sandy beach is on your right side.

name: Delta gas station
description:
They have a large off road site next to the gas station. When we arrived at 19.30hrs it was empty.
We asked if we could park and was told no problem.
A couple of HGV have pulled up next to us but they haven't kept their engines running.
Not a bad place if you're running out of time. 
We ran out of time.🤗

name: Casa Yayaz  Hotel & Camping
description:
Gated, Safe! Please text or call before arriving! CLOSED AT 6PM. +506 60666751. RESERVATIONS ARE ESSENTIAL! 
Newly added feature: covered parking for longterm camping  on-site guard..Sorry Credit Cards  NOT  accepted
Newly renovated, electricity at all sites. 4 new covered sites! 

MAX HEIGHT VEHICLE is 3 meters (10 feet).

An Oasis in a tropical Paradise, all for 12K Colones/vehicle with 2 persons per night ! 10%DISCOUNT for 2 days or more. 
(8.000 for each EXTRA person after 2). Leashed Pets OK
Fully-equipped kitchen, plus indoor living space, hot water showers, gated parking area, beautifully landscaped covered outdoor picnic tables, and $5 laundry. GREAT WIFI

Phone / WhatsApp: +1 5066066 6751

Laundry facilities! Birdwatching, peaceful location, easy access, well-marked sign, (CASA YAYAZ) ample room for parking. some shade. pets on a leash. Centrally located.

name: Hacienda Sassenberg
description:
MODERATOR NOTE: Description provided by owner.  

We are a hacienda with 200 ha in the mountains of Miramar, Puntarenas and lie at 720m above sea level.
For our guests,  there are 3 bungalows as well as a campsite and a pool available. We also offer a very good breakfast for $ 12 pp (typical or continental).
From our hacienda, you have a beautiful view of the Gulf of Nicoya and the Nicoya Peninsula as well as the cloud forest.
The night per car or per tent for 2 pers is US$ 20
Additional children up to 6 years stay for free.
Additional children or adults 8 years and older pay US$ 5 pp.
Use of electricity large camper ( air conditioning )$ 2 per day,
Free cell phones and computers, use of facilities and swimming pool FREE, children under 8 years under adult supervision. Wifi free.
We also offer various adventure tours such as horseback riding, ATV´s, Zip Lining, and more.
The average temperature during the day is 28 C° (82,4F°).
The average temperature during the night is 22C° (71,6F°).

Please send a message by WhatsApp at +(506) 88566366 or +(506) 89747101. Jazmin & Heiko Sassenberg

name: Mirador - Trail
description: Amazing view over the ocean. Trail is shady in nice Forest, really quiet. Would be nice to sleep up here in a tent

name: Parking Mata de Limon
description: Big parking area close to the harbour. Good for spending a night after arrival with the ferry in Puntarenas. Guarded.

name: Sunset Eco Boatyard
description: Marina, which is operated by a French guy. He and his staff were really helpful and they assisted me with ordering some glue and providing tools for fixing the cabin of our motorhome. We were even allowed to spent the night on the premises. If you need a place for spending the night only, take the parking area, which is 50 m away. If you need to get your rig fixed, come to this place. You need to enter via the harbour entrance. Then make a right and follow the railroad tracks.

name: Cruz Roja
description: We asked at Cruz Roja and they said that we can stay there one night. Very kind and helpful. Shower and toilets available. Center of the town.

name: Bomberos Ciudad Quesada
description: Nice people, they let us stay in there visitor's parking for one night. We used the toilets in the evening and in the morning but it's closed during the night. We felt safe.

name: Bridge
description: Bridge not passable with heavy motorhomes. Limit is 4t and height limit is approx. 2,4m. Couldn't pass with a MAN truck.

name: Cascada elysiana
description: Nice ecolodge with dorm and luxury tents. 5min walk from a beautiful waterfall. Cool yogaplatform.

name: Los Laureles
description: nice little hotel and restaurant. The owner is very friendly and helpful, he gave us a lot of tips about the most beautiful beaches and the nationalparks around. We had a double Room with warm showers and a/c and he charged us 45 US. We were there by bicycle but there is space for big rigs as well. Absolutely recommended.

name: Taller Salazar
description:
We found this place whilst searching for a replacement cylinder head for our 1992 Mercedes 814DA. Autostar (Mercedes Dealer) could only source one from Germany.
It is a family business, the son works on cars whilst the father specializes in heavy vehicles. 
They have many Mercedes/Unimog vehicles and spare parts available.
They realigned our belts, changed the radiator fan to suit the climate, sorted a diesel leak and refurbished our starter motor.
Very friendly people. They don't speak English but Google translate works well.
They are happy for overlanders to stay in the secure yard overnight with their vehicles if they need to. We were repaired in 1 day. No facilities.

name: frenos y muflas alajuela
description:
Super nice garage! A1 service.

They changed my alternator bearing and they managed to bring my parts to a place that have a hydraulic press and to find another bearing too all by themselves.

They seems to do all kind of jobs. 

Very good service and good people.

Highly recommend.

name: Malecon Restaurant
description:
We managed to park right next to the river outside this restaurant.
Good food and WiFi. We arrived Saturday afternoon and were joined by locals who stayed awake all night. Not too noisy I must say.
Beautiful beach and the town isn't in your face too touristy, if that makes sense.

name: Camping las Brisas
description:
Nice camping place with little roofs for shade and rain cover. Toilets and cold shower, but sometimes they are locked for some reason. Place is directly in front of the ocean. We stayed one night and paid 8000c for 2p and a car with rooftop tent.
You can see many aras and really big lizards are in the trees.

name: Balbo’s Liberia
description:
“Balbo’s”-a place where world travelers meet!
At our crocodile river borders the dry- forest of Liberia where our camping and hostel are located. In this beautiful area we organize various hikings and horseback rides. Also we are also happy to serve traditional food for breakfast, lunch or dinner. The bar with ice-cold drinks is open throughout the day and evening. 

SAVE PARKING PLACE!

We are Dutch-owners. 
Our son, your fantastic host!; speaks Spanish, Dutch, English and A little bit german.

tel: +506 64664747 email: balboscr@gmail.com

We give a free Balbo-tour for Overlanders!!

name: End of the malecon, Quepos.
description:
Great place to stay overnight and really close to town. Beautiful view over the beach. If it wasn't raining we would have had a sunset.
Electrical sockets on the nearby lampost. Picnic benches and skateboard park. Very busy with locals in the afternoon enjoying the sea breeze.
We caught the bus at the station to El Avion restaurant and after lunch walked into Manuel Antonio.
Quepos is a busily little town with lots of restaurants, shops and friendly people.
You can relax here and dream about owning one of the many boats in the marina.

name: Playa Piñuelas
description: Nice little beach near the marino park from Uvita. Seems to be that in early days this beach was part of it, but now everything is broken and really old. The office, showers, the sink. No facilities are working anymore. We saw a small sign with camping area so we thought it is fine to stay one night. We didn't swim because of rain and the big waves. But the parking is fine with good ground and no mud. You can hear the noise from the street and everywhere there are signs that you should care about your belongings, but we felt safe.

name: Soulsurfer
description: Beautiful burger restaurant right at the beach. Delicious homemade burgers. Great variety: Meat, chicken, fish, vegetarian and vegan burgers, also gluten free burgers! Nice atmosphere, friendly staff and good music.

name: Chocolate and Coffee
description:
This stretch of road is pretty hectic and due to an accident I was delayed awhile. It got dark and the rain was hammering down hard.  So I decided to find a (big-rig friendly) place to park. 
This is A small roadside ‘strip mall’ with restaurant, cafe, mini-super All were closed when I arrived and parking lot empty. The bathrooms were still open until I went to bed and so I don’t know what time (if at all) they get locked.
Acceptable place to stay the night at the side of the highway.

name: Krystalmax
description:
Really nice pink building owned by an french canadian.

Super super nice guy speak english french and Spanish!!

Mucho recommand

name: Good Mechanic - large vehicle equipped
description: Needed suspension work done - broken leaf spring. Good mechanics, fair price, fit us in day of and had the truck back in a few hours. Recommended!

name: Charlie’s Angels Animal Rescue
description:
Feb 2022 update: dog rescue is currently not running at this location!
Do a little good! Wonderful dog/cat rescue in set up in the highlands. Really a great place to visit particularly if you are a dog lover. There is a communal house for access to bathrooms (showers), kitchen, WiFi, etc.  Gated and secure parking places available in the yard under some beautiful fruit trees. Electric may be available with a long extension cord. Not really suited to big rigs but great for small to medium (I’m traveling in a full size truck with pop-top camper). Lots of hiking trails close by, may also be a good option for parking if you plan to hike Chirripo. The rescue is always in need of good volunteers for dog walks and chores around the house. You can stay without volunteering but the dogs are so cute I doubt you’ll want to. I stayed 2 weeks and loved my time here! Watching the dogs and puppies change and grow is priceless. I also travel with a dog and having him with me was no problem (dogs must be good with other dogs and cats). Price: $10.00/night. Fee goes DIRECTLY back into the animal rescue so you know it is going to a good place.

name: Posada San Isidro Labrador
description:
Nice little place along the highway. I skipped past San José, and tried to find something in Cartago, but everything was quite expensive. 
Really clean and large rooms, nicest bed I’ve had in 3 months on the road. 
My room has a huge entranceway/closet. Couple cots, a mini fridge. 
A bit of road noise, but it’s negligible. Open parking, but a covered roof portion for bikes. 
Most but the largest of rigs would fit I think

name: Siaxola/Guabito bordercrossing, Immigration and Customs office Costa Rica.
description: The Costa Rica Immigration and Aduana office are here. Didn’t use restroom. The exit tax paying machine out of order. Electricity worked fine. We were in and out in under 40 minutes

name: Gasolinera La Palma Chacarita
description: big gaz station with toilet, free cold shower, small shop y restaurant. Friendly staff let us sleep in our car, open 24h.

name: Las Mercedes Coffee Farm
description:
Family owned coffee farm surrounded by Cloud Forest - 
Historical Farmhouse - Specialty Coffee - Hiking Destination.
Us$10 per person per night. 
Please call or whatsapp in advance +506 6086 2030 (Mela)

name: Butterfly Conservatory
description: Great rainforest regeneration project. They have a butterfly farm with 4 different habitats and a frog habitat as well. Also a nice and short hike through the rainforest and a nice viewpoint to the lake and the volcano. They take your time and give you a tour after that you can do the hike on your own. Lots of hummingbirds around. 15$ pp. Open 8-16 every day. Well worth the money!

name: Cafe de Monteverde
description: We booked a tour and could stay over night. Jason was really friendly. There is a flat spot surrounded with trees. The restroom and shower is open all night. They offert us to pick fruits and vegetables out of there garden. In the morning you get free coffee!

name: VANAGON MECHANIC - Fabián Herrera
description:
An actual true real life vanagon nut in Central America. We were after rear springs for ours and through a chat and a referral and another referral found Fabián. Truly great help, has lots of used spares and if you message him enough in advance might be able to help you get you new parts. He has Synchro and 2wd parts. Saw electrical parts, lights, suspension etc stripped from a few donors over the years.
Even took us out in his synchro beast and filled our water tank from the potable hose. Helped us change the springs right there on his driveway.
His number is +506 7200 7197. WhatsApp works, and Google translate if you don't speak Spanish. 
If you struggle to find the entrance to the house drive around till you see vanagons.

name: just another down by the river
description:
Near a dam we found a small track down to a small river. Was boggy by the river so stayed at the top where there's a small turn around spot we wedged into. Visible from the road but feels safe and mega low traffic volume. 
Kinda steep climb off the road but was ok when wet in 2wd vanagon. Front wheel drives may struggle.

name: Bahia El Torno
description:
Good place to stay in a wonderful bay.
Easy access on paved road. Good for one night after or before border crossing. Very quiet at night and we felt very safe.

name: Queso Canaàn
description: The Family Mata Hernández sells homemade cheese here! Swiss recipes, cheese with herbs and many more! They even give you some samples! Best cheese in Central America for us ;)

name: Hotel Bristol
description: Nice little hotel close to airport. Good breakfast ! perfect for a stay before traveling further

name: Hostel Sámara
description:
Very nice and clean hostel. Dorms with fan for 15$ pp. Big well-equipped kitchen and nice common areas. 
Owner is super friendly and full of advice. There is space for bikes and motorbikes inside. Otherwise, you can park on the street close to the entrance and they will watch your car during the night. Decent WiFi (slow) and also AC rooms available if you prefer that.

name: Police Station
description: We spotted a hose outside so stopped to ask if we could fill up our shower (which they said was no problem), and they said it was potable too. Just ask nicely to one of the officers inside if you can use first!

name: Next to the Police Station
description: In the evening we asked in the police station if we can set up our tent next to the building. There is a huge area of grass and gravel which is used as a parking lot for the police staff as well. It was no problem for them to pass the night there and I think with a camper it wouldn't be a problem either. Good place to stay.

name: Cabina Roca Mar
description: Chill clean Cabina with a hot shower and a very nice lady that runs the place! Bit pricey but we were drenched from rain and dirty from the cycle. Wifi is good a/c is good. Paid 20,000 colons

name: Thermomania
description: Thermal water with facilities, cabins, restaurant, grills. Small water park. Free parking overnight at front parking lot. Open from 8 to 22h. Now 12000₡ p/p.

name: Luxury Hostel
description:
This is a great hostel! We stayed here in the 16 beds dorm (in reality a 12 bed-dorm) and we had it nearly for our own. We payed 4600 Colones ( 7.50 Dollars) per bed. Breakfast with toast, fruits and cereals is included. The shower is a dream! There is a kitchen as well and in the lobby one can play table soccer, table tennis and billiard for free or you can just chill in the pool. 
There are private rooms as well and dorms with shutters at the beds for saving the privacy. 
Busses going for 350 Colones (50 cents) to San José Centre. Big supermarket is only two blocks away. 

One of the best hostels we've ever been!

name: Playa Loros/ Playa Punta de Pelencho
description: Beautiful lonesome beach camping! No amenities but a very pretty bay with an island to walk over! Police pops by once in a while! Recommended!

name: Airport Costa Rica B&B
description:
If you need to storage your car for a while this is an excellent option! We left our car and trailer for over a month at Fernando's place and everything went perfect. It is really close to the airport and in case you need it, you can rent a room in their B&B for $50 USD. It's clean, comfy and best of all, pet friendly. 

The entrance is gated, and the parking area is next to the owners houses, so you don't need to worry about safety at all.

$5 USD per day

name: Supermarket Media Luna
description: This is a modern family-run supermarket with high-quality products and also contains a little cafe with a great bakery section. Perfect stop to quickly grab some groceries or to have a break along the way.  Good coffee!

name: Bomberos
description: Good spot for bike tourists to camp for a night. Shower, kitchen, grassy area, Wi-Fi and most important: Friendly staff!

name: Beach
description: This place is a paradise for bikers/hikers. Imagine camping out on a beach that feels like it's made for you (I haven't seen anybody), surrounded by coconut trees that enable you to make your own Rice & Beans and to top it off: There is an awesome night sky if you're lucky with the clouds. Stop imagining and camp right here, there is an entrance on the side of the road. No facilities. Don't leave your garbage please.

name: Cabinas Padaroda
description:
Great place to stop, if like us, you got stuck at dusk and didn’t make it to Puerto Viejo! Very friendly owners. Felt very safe here. 

Large, gated and flat gravel parking lot in front of the cabinas for parking with trees and plants around, grass and trees beyond. Covered tables and spaces we used for outdoor cooking & sink we used to clean dishes. Power outlet available for hookup.  7,000 colones for both of us. Washroom available but no shower (unless you pay for a room). It’s right off the highway, so you will hear traffic, as well as frogs and crickets.

Rooms also available with private washroom, kitchenette and A/C for 13,000 colones and can sleep 3 (2 beds). Rooms are clean and comfortable looking, well maintained. We think we’re the first people to camp here, but she said more overlanders are welcome. We did not ask about tents, though there would be space on grassy areas.

Apparently malaria is an issue here, so keep yourself covered/ sprayed. 

There are dogs on the property (we never saw them) so unsure if it would be pet friendly.

name: Campyng Bar El Indio
description:
Hard soil under shady trees. Clean toilets and basic outside shower.
3500 CRC pP/night; 5000 CRC pP/night with breakfast.
We didn‘t stay there because we wanted to proceed, but the place seems to be agreable and safe. Beautiful beaches nearby. We would have stayed if it would have fit at our travel schedule.

name: In front the police
description: We park in front the police, they are very kindly with us and feel safe.

name: Bomba Huacas
description:
We were on the way to Playa Conchal, without safe options to sleep. So, we stopped in this gas stations and asked for stop here to sleep. They said it was okay, we used their toilets and water to fuel our tank, giving them a tip. It was okay, not too much noise and they had a truck sleeping here also. 
***
Estávamos a caminho de Playa Conchal, sem opções seguras para dormir. Então, paramos neste posto de gasolina e pedimos para parar aqui para dormir. Eles disseram que tudo bem, usamos seus banheiros e água para abastecer nosso tanque, dando-lhes uma gorjeta. Tudo correu bem, sem muito barulho e eles tinham um caminhão dormindo aqui também.

name: On the street
description: We park here 2 nights with no problem, near the beach and feel safe

name: Hostel Tortuga camping
description:
Great hostel, with a river in the backyard and just minutes from beautiful beaches! (4 minutes to a swimming beach & 10 for surfing). Access to kitchen, toilets, showers, WiFi, electricity for charging phones etc, pool, river, plus they’ll provide towels and soap if you need. 

We went on the recommendation of some local friends and it turned out to be a brilliant spot. It’s just off the main road, so super easy to reach, but because of the amount of nature around, you really don’t hear the road. Plus you have access to a beautiful river to cool off in (just meters from the front door!) 

Camping is on a grassy area just outside the hostel, but as the road dead-ends at the river, it’s not a through-road so you’re just parked in the middle of the jungle, it’s great! 

$25 for two people with car (additional $5 pp for extra people in the same car). 

Also, to a laundry machine (wager & dryer). $6 of you do it yourself, $12 if you leave stuff to be washed. 

Mari and Fabio (Costa Rican / Swiss couple) are brilliant. Super welcoming and have lots of info about places nearby, including a beautiful waterfall. 

Definitely recommend.

name: Coral Reef Surf Hostal
description: Lovely little Hostal with 2x private parking gated spaces. No height limit but wouldn't want a long wheel base. Close to the beach. $50 for a 4 person room in high season.

name: laboratorio diesel-taller Santamaria
description: Helliot and sons are true diesel performance specialists. Very knowleadgeble and really friendly. Prices are very good versus Costa Rican standards. very recommended! you can find them in Facebook: Laboratorio Diesel Taller Santamaria LDTS

name: Restaurants/ Hostel parking lot
description: Small parking lot located behind the line of restaurants and next to the Arenal container hostel. Free bathrooms right by the parking and free WiFi from the neighbouring hostel. We paid the container hostel for use of their facilities in advance but in hindsight really didn't need to. You can definitely just park here and camp for free. Guy who owns propane shop is a camping enthusiast too and wants to make this trip. Feels super safe. FREE

name: Viewpoint to sea with sunrise and sunset
description:
We went to “You are in the Costa Rica”, a recommended point but Mariane and Marcos said that the parking near them was a private land and they didn’t allow someone put it on the app. So they recommended this place. Wonderful! Quiet and with stunning view. We arrived at sunset and there is just 2 guys looking at, after in the sunrise came a couple, but it was okay. It is isolated but not too much as there are some houses near (200m/400m). Quiet and safe.
***
Nós fomos em “You are Costa Rica”, um lugar recomendado pelo app, mas Marcos e Mariane não nos autorizaram ficar lá, porque o estacionamento é uma terra privada e eles não autorizaram que fosse colocado no app. Então nos indicaram esse lugar onde há uma bela vista e se pode ver o pôr-do-sol e o nascer do sol. É muito bonito. Quando chegamos havia dois caras assistindo pôr-do-sol e pela manhã um casal assistiu o nascer do sol, mas tudo bem. Estamos isolados mas ao mesmo tempo não totalmente pois há duas casas próximas (200 m, 400 m), tranquilo e seguro.
***
Nous sommes d’abord allé à « You are Costa Rica », recommandé par l’application. Finalement le lieu n’est pas approprié car c’est le parking du voisin. 
Marcos le propriétaire nous a indiqué un autre endroit bien plus sympa. Le lieu surplombe la ville et permet de se coucher / lever avec une vue sublime sur la mer. Site tranquille, sûr et un peu isolé (une maison à 200m). Peu fréquenté car connu des locaux. 
Très bon choix!!

name: Garden House
description: Hiked Cerro Chirripo and was able to park at this cafe/house for free for 1 night in exchange for eating lunch at the cafe upon our return. Food cost $4,000 colones per dish (pasta) and it tasted great!

name: Viewpoint
description: There are couple pullouts along this road with amazing view of San Jose (especially at night). On the weekends it gets packed by locals hanging out. Around eleven they start leaving. Night was quiet. Nobody bothered us.

name: Ferreteria Tecnica (Hardware store)
description: This is a really nice store for any plomber problems, and other constructions stuff. People really helpful and good prices.

name: farmers market
description: Big empty lot where farmer markets operates on Tuesdays. Plenty space to wild camp shaded areas two

name: Square
description: Huge Gras quarter mas o menos in town.. looks good for a night

name: Rancho del Sabito
description: Huge area very friendly economic... RV friendly flat Free

name: Pali supermarket
description: Cashier told us water from tap in the bathroom is safe to drink. We filled our 20l jug there. Apparently all tap water in Costa Rica is good to drink, except in some rare very remote places...

name: check point
description: This was a checkpoint looking for drugs or guns. They said they were going to bring dogs to sniff around but we said that's fine and that we dont have any drugs (which we actually don't). They looked through a few things and tried to be a little intimidating but it was fine in the end. They seem pretty keen on finding drugs here this is the second time weve been searched in this region. Were not driv9ng some crazy looking hippy van either just a plain white newer model ford. So it just just be all foreign people, they didnt seem too concerned with latin american looking drivers.
